X.T: Magdalena Olak - ISTQB CTFL Syllabus 2018 V3.1

BLIST.TITLE: Specialty sites
BLIST.ITEM:
Pairwise Testinghttps://www.pairwise.org/
enHTML: combinatorial test case generation

Lorem Ipsumhttps://www.lipsum.com/
enHTML: generate sample text

Random User Generatorhttps://randomuser.me
enHTML: generate random persons

BLIST.TITLE: Screenshot tools
BLIST.ITEM:
Winkhttps://www.debugmode.com/wink.html
enHTML: recording a film of the screen

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic information about testing (requirement writing, test prioritisation, reporting…). There is nothing new here, but this description is interestingly down to earth.
The very well-known software testing sample.

The author gives a good list of errors commonly done, I have already met several of them. The list is not exhaustive, the proposed solutions could have been more analysed, but this is a good brain catalyst to think about how to improve your testing.
CemKaner describes some trivial and some more interesting facts on testing (especially about good enough quality).

X.T: What's So Different About Game Testing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why is game testing different from testing usual applications?
How to prove to managers the value of testing…
A good checklist to design test strategies.

X.T: We’ve only got One Life to Live, so we shouldn’t waste it on ineffective test design. Follow this Guiding Light to The Bold and the Beautiful world of Soap Opera Testing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of soap opera tests and how to manage them.

X.T: The Ongoing Revolution in Software Testing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Debunking some false ideas about testing.

X.T: How To Recruit, Motivate, and Energize Superior Test Engineers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A test manager at CISCO explains how he hires and retains test engineers.

X.T: Proving Our Worth: Quantifying the Value of Testing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: LeeCopeland starts by looking for a definition of testing. Then, he speaks about the goal/question/metric model and the fact that some companies collect metrics without any purpose. He explains that information should be accurate, timely, complete, relevant, unique, and actionable. He finishes by explaining the information that developers, test managers, and project managers would like to have. This lecture is interesting, but too much abstract. For example, in most cases, it is impossible to give a dollar estimation of a bug.
Some research on software testing: randomised tests (I used this around 1994…), mutant generator, Tarantula…

BertrandMeyer presents some interesting ideas, for example the fact that testing strategies must be assessed. But I tend to sometimes disagree: testing is not only finding bugs, but it is also checking that common use scenarios are successfully supported; adding a new test for every found bug will result into a chaos if there isn’t a good testing infrastructure…
If the function being tested has some particularities (symmetry, recurrence relations…), it is possible to generate new test cases from existing ones.
A short feedback on the three libraries.
A short presentation of Rapid Software Testing.

X.T: “The Shoe Test” – does this test really add value??

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This blog entry contains little more than the question.

X.T: TestBash 2.0 - A-Galumphing We Go James Bach

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Galumphing is simply adding inert variations in test procedure to find bugs.
JimmyBogard gives feedback on his testing experience: fast tests / slow tests / slow as hell tests, behavioural tests vs. procedural tests, xUnit, AutoFixture, Should, don’t mock internals…

X.T: Kent Beck : “I get paid for code that works, not for tests”

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some thoughts about KentBeck’s quote.
The business should write automated acceptance tests (instead of a QA test plan).
Method extraction can be used to improve the readability of a test, but it must be used adequately.
Adding generative tests to unit tests, in order to further check the production code.
Some parallels between testing and counting plankton, but there is nothing interesting here.

X.T: On the Quality of Qualitative Measures

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Want to introduce fewer bugs? Test through these five cases.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Test the following cases: null, 0, 1, 3 and "a lot".
The definitions of different types of tests and the fact that the tests should be first class citizens, hence should be decoupled from the production code.
Some interesting and common sense analysis of how MarcHage Chahine could have done better.

X.T: Analyse de mes principales erreurs – la suite

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The (late) continuation of the previous article.

X.T: Test Driving a Blockchain Application: A Simple Example

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic ideas about a test strategy for verifying a blockchain, but these is nothing noticeable here.

X.T: Testopsies Dissecting Your Testing - James Bach and Michael Bolton

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Recording videos during test sessions and analysing them to better understand our testing process.

X.T: 5 Test Management Tools Review | 5 Alternatives of JIRA and Quality Center | Must Watch for Testers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Short presentations of TestMonitor, TestLodge, Practitest, TestCollab, and TestCaseLab.

X.T: PREMIER: Michael Bolton: What’s Wrong with Manual Testing?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The manual vs. automated test dichotomy is wrong, this video is interesting if you have never seen MichaelBolton or JamesBach before, otherwise there is nothing new here.

X.T: Coup de Gueule: arrêtez de me parler de 0 Bug!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This blog states the obvious: it is meaningless to speak about a target of zero bugs.

X.T: Que fait un bon testeur ? Bah… il teste!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This article is not about the quality of a tester, but it is a list of the activities of a tester, with some spelling mistakes.
JamesBach explains why, while he acts currently as a developer, he is not able to test his own product and needs someone else for this.
An interview of a test lead. There is nothing remarkable here, but this gives a view on this job.

X.T: Résultats du sondage : quel futur pour le test ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A small survey of 200+ French testers.

X.T: Marc Hage Chahine : Comment prédire les anomalies ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of well-known ideas, many not related to the prediction of defaults, some of these (e.g. the broken windows theory) are wrongly explained.

X.T: Zoé Thivet : Testers under test : les bugs mentaux des testeurs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The idea of presenting cognitive biases than may impact testers is good, but the presentation is not convincing, probably because it is not enough detailed.

X.T: Duel: tests système vs tests fonctionnels

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An unclear description of functional tests vs. system tests, with the usual spelling mistakes.
The confusion between agile’s user story acceptance test and ISTQB’s user acceptance test.

X.T: Coup de gueule: arrêter avec « le test c’est pour les testeurs »!

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Stating the obvious (but maybe there are indeed some dumb persons who believe the opposite): tester are the only ones responsible of the quality.
The author debunks some wrong ideas about tests on an agile environments. These ideas are obviously wrong, but maybe some persons really believe in these.

X.T: An overview of the Agile Testing Quadrants

ARTICLE.COMMENT: BrianMarick’quadrants described by a test automation engineer.

X.T: How To Generate Manual Test Cases Automatically With Screenshot | Testcase Studio

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of TestCase Studio, a browser plugin to capture the interactions with the browser and generate a manual test. I do not understand the point of such a tool in 2023…

X.T: We all need to become critical testers | Tanja Vos | TEDxOpenUniversiteitHeerlen

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some long story telling just to state the obvious: AI systems need to be tested by humans.

X.T: Article 1/3 : L’automatisation de tests dans un environnement sécurisé avec de l’authentification multi-facteur – Jonathan Bernales

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The interest of using MFA and several MFA mechanisms.

X.T: Tests E2E automatisés avec Authentification Multi-facteur – Jonathan Bernales

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Why testing with MFA disabled is a bad idea and some little information on manual and automated testing of an application which uses MFA.

X.T: Article 3/3 : Industrialisation de tests MFA et introduction au RPA – Jonathan Bernales

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some tricks to manage MFA tokens across test team members. But I do not understand why JonathanBernales added a paragraph about RPA.

X.T: Automatiser les tests MFA par SMS avec Playwright : Tutoriel complet et pratique

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An example of a Playwright test using GetMyMFA to test an MFA authentication using an SMS.

X.T: GenAI & Qualité Logicielle en 2024 : Tendances, réalités et cas concrets

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A demo of Sogeti’s Gen AI Amplifier on user stories and tests generation. This is interesting, but I wonder how much is bullshit…

X.T: L’apport des LLM sur le test

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic information about using LLMs for test, the ony interesting part is the demo of Sogeti’s Gen AI Amplifier (more or less the same as in the previous video) if it would have been fully presented.

X.T: Les niveaux de test ont-ils leur place en Agile ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some small thought about the test levels, the testing quadrants, V-lifecycle, and agile.

X.T: Interview: les agents IA pour le test

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It would be difficult to give less informations about how AI agents can help testers…

X.T: Mieux tester avec l’IA – Ep1 : Où passe le temps des équipes QA ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Jean-FrançoisFresi is 20 years late… What is the rationale for writing detailed test scenarios to be executed by human-robots?

X.T: Mieux tester avec l’IA – Ep2 : Les défis de l’exécution manuelle des tests

ARTICLE.COMMENT: JulienBotella tells some basic facts about automated and manual tests, Jean-FrançoisFresi tries to complement with some comments, many of these are silly.

X.T: Mieux tester avec l’IA – Ep3 : Automatisation, un “Solublème” ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: On one side, they are giving basic and (mostly) correct opinions on test automation, which may be interesting for those who have no clue about the subject, and, on the other side, they do not give detailed rationales, so newbies may not be able to really understand.

X.T: Mieux tester avec l’IA – Ep4 : Quand l’IA s’invite dans la QA

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Jean-FrançoisFresi and JulienBotella are talking about commonplaces about AI. Nothing false, but all of this is known by everyone.

X.T: Mieux tester avec l’IA – Ep5 : Quelle solution pour exécuter les tests manuels ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: JulienBotella gives a high-level description of Lynqa. It is difficult to guess if that tool has any value.

X.T: Interview: créer et animer une formation sur l’IA dans le test

ARTICLE.COMMENT: AnneKramer speaks about Smartesting’s training on testing using AI, but this is generic stuff with no information about the training content.
James gives a realistic view of automatic testing.
CemKaner is debunking the claims that there is a real separation between automated test and manual tests, and that checking is not testing.

X.T: James Bach on Systems Thinking (made with Spreaker)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Context-Driven School vs. the ISTQB School, answering critics, devops and system thinking.

X.T: A Context-Driven Approach to Automation in Testing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another explanation that test automation is not something that can be done dumbly.

X.T: Reviewing "Context Driven Approach to Automation in Testing"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A negative review of the previous paper: it is FUD and outdated.
ElisabethHendrickson shares her experience of being a tester in an XP team: this is a very practical and interesting paper…
The same information as in the article above, but, here, you get additionally her full dynamism.
An interesting group discussion on Scrum and QA.

X.T: Exploratory Testing in an Agile Context

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A tutorial explaining some ways to perform exploratory testing.

X.T: Does It Work? Are We Done? Is It Right? (Keep It Light!)

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
(The transcript is available in Does It Work? Are We Done? Is It Right? (Keep It Light!)https://www.jamesshore.com/v2/blog/2007/does-it-work-are-we-done
enHTML) TDD is the solution to minimise waste when checking if the software works properly and it is complete.
A short presentation of Exploratory Testing.
JamesBach describes what he calls Exploratory Testing: having bright minds executing tests designed on the fly. I can only agree with him: this works only if the tester is good.

X.ST: You don’t always need to wait for complete specifications to start your testing effort.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A short introduction to Exploratory Testing and the HICCUPPS heuristics.

(The slides are available in Breaking Down (and building up) Exploratory Testing Skillhttp://cfs7.tistory.com/upload_control/download.blog?fhandle=YmxvZzk3ODE0QGZzNy50aXN0b3J5LmNvbTovYXR0YWNoLzAvOS5wZGY%3D&filename=ET_dynamics_Google_3_06.pdf
enPDF.) JonBach gives some information about exploratory testing. He lists 14 usable tactics ("MRQ COMP GRABC R&R?"). This is a good brain teaser, but the presentation is rather messy.
MichaelBolton completes his list of heuristics.
A short presentation of exploratory testing.

X.T: Les Tests Exploratoires, Une obligation dans l’agilité ??

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of exploratory testing, the proposed organisation is more or less applicable, but the author’s definition of exploratory testing is too narrow and there are too many spelling mistakes.

JamesBach explains that models are always wrong and you will miss bugs if you blindly base your tests on such a model. During the Q&A session, James discusses about some of his favourite subjects: MIPping (mention in passing), blink testing…
The title says it all.

X.T: Gérer vos tests avec Squash TM

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of the product.

X.T: Squash TM : 8 astuces et bonnes pratiques

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some good basic advice.

X.T: Webinar Squash #10 - Aperçu de la nouvelle interface de Squash

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A preview of the new UI of Squash TM 2.0.

X.T: Squash a 10 ans, retour sur l'évolution de notre stratégie Produit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: YEST 3.0 - Logiciel de conception et implémentation visuelles de test en agile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The new features: retrieval of the requirements from Jira and ALM, modification management and fix suggestions, and sticky notes.

X.T: The complete guide to Xray Test Management for Jira

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title is misleading, this is not a guide but a marketing overview.

X.T: Announcing Automation Launching for Testmo Enterprise

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Users can now launch automated tests from Testmo to execute them in GitHub Actions or GitLab CI/CD.

X.T: Top 10 Takeaways from the Inaugural Testmo User Survey

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some results from the Testmo User Survey and the next months roadmap.

X.T: ChatGPT for Gherkin, BDD and Test Automation

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This guy seems to know how to properly use ChatGPT, but the example he choose (login to a site) is the worst possible, this just demonstrates that ChatGPT can generate some Gherkin, not that it can design good test cases.

X.T: Unlocking the Power of ChatGPT and AI in Testing: A Real World Look, presented by Applitools

ARTICLE.COMMENT:
Yet another video of a guy who does not master what he talks about: he does not know that ChatGPT cannot access Internet and does not spot that some answers are just hallucination (the slides are herehttps://www.slideshare.net/slideshow/embed_code/key/bSiFS2ewEYeMLW
enHTML).

X.T: Addressing the risks of Exploratory Testing (Part 1)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to test without test scripts: doing analysis sessions to review the test approach and new comers are better welcomed by working on the knowledge base rather than by executing a test plan.

X.T: Addressing the Risks of Exploratory Testing: Part 2

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The continuation of the previous blog: analysis sessions make it easier to replace a sick tester, mind-maps demonstrate the work done to the project team, and a framework such as Session Based Test Management can be use to ensure traceability and auditability.
People often impose themselves limits that to do really exit. Many persons do not push questioning far enough to get all the information they need.

X.T: Is lack of trust affecting your testing?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Having a more productive off-shore team by improving the communication between the on-shore team and the off-shore team and building trust.
A comparison of the two certifications.
Instead of trying to mitigate any possible risk by running all existing tests, we should design the tests depending on the risks on the product.
Using a Visual Test Model, i.e. a mindmap representing the test coverage.
Context Driven Testing and Agile are a good match, but this blog is too polished.
James explains how you, being a good tester, can reach the status of being a testing expert. This does not speak about testing tools or methodologies, but on the state of mind you should have.

X.T: Open Lecture by James Bach on Software Testing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A longer, updated version of the previous presentation.
Roy describes the MethodName_StateUnderTest_ExpectedBehaviour naming convention for unit tests.

X.T: Refactoring and Design Skills for Test Driven Development SA2013

ARTICLE.COMMENT: (Conference: Software Architect 2013) How to do TDD for brand new applications and for legacy applications. There is nothing new in the first part, but this is still a good TDD explanation. The part about legacy code is more interesting because less frequently spoken about.
A good tutorial on how to write unit tests and an introduction to TDD.

X.T: Unit Testing Best Practices with Roy Osherove

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some good advice on writing good unit tests, i.e. unit tests which are trustworthy, maintainable and readable.
A presentation of system isolation: a tutorial on isolation, an explanation of mock vs. stub, a demo of NUnit, Rhino Mocks and Typemock’s Isolator.

X.T: Mocking on the Edge - Isolation at the system level

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of Typemock Open-AOP API and how to use it for stubbing Sharepoint and Silverlight.
